RAT PCR : RAT AND PCR TESTS FOR COVID-19 PERFORMED FROM 2019-
(a) Will he inform this House, separately-
(i) the total number of Rapid Antigen Tests (RAT) and the Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) tests for COVID-19 performed by the Government and the private sector in Sri Lanka from 2019 to 2022;
(ii) the names of the registered local agents for each of the aforesaid tests with the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA);
(b) Will he also inform this House, separately -
(i) the unit cost incurred by the government sector for Rapid Antigen Tests (RATs) and the Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) test; and
(ii) the total cost for Rapid Antigen Tests (RATs) and the Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) tests incurred by the government sector for the period from 2019 to 2022?
(c) If not, why? ( ) (The Hon. Prasanna Ranatunga) , * .

SRI LANKA CRICKET: FUNDS RECEIVED AND EXPENDITURE
asked the Minister of Sports and Youth Affairs:
(i) the sources from which the Sri Lanka Cricket receives its funds;
(ii) the mechanisms implemented to ensure that the aforementioned funds are used in a productive manner;
(iii) separately, the value of fixed deposits of the aforesaid institution from year 2015 to date, according to each year; and
(iv) separately, the expenditure of the aforementioned institution during the aforesaid period, according to each year?
(b) If not, why? ( ) (The Hon. Roshan Ranasinghe) , * .

(i) the bus stand at Kekirawa Town, which is used by a large number of commuters, is very old; and
(ii) it is unusable during the rainy season?
(b) If so, will he inform this House whether steps will be taken to repair the said bus station?

Alawathuwala Hon. Jayarathna Herath Hon. K. Sujith Sanjaya Perera Hon. Nalin Bandara Jayamaha Hon. Dilip Wedaarachchi Hon. (Mrs.) Thalatha Athukorala, Attorney at Law Hon. Ishak Rahuman Hon. Ajith Mannapperuma Hon. Hector Appuhamy Hon. Mayantha Dissanayake Hon. Rohana Bandara Hon. Mano Ganesan Hon. Vijitha Herath Hon. M. Udayakumar Hon. (Dr.) (Ms.) Harini Amarasuriya Hon. Field Marshal Sarath Fonseka, - Vote of No Confidence against Hon. Keheliya Rambukwella, Minister of Health, - Whereas solutions have not been put forward so far for the crisis that has arisen in the health sector at present;

And whereas the opinion of the experts is that most of the sorrowful incidents that are reported from hospitals day by day are deaths and impairments caused due to the use of drugs which either substandard or are low in quality;

And whereas he is accountable as the Minister of Health for not duly appointing the Board of Directors of the National Medicines Regulatory Authority, for the importing of low quality drugs, for the importing of drugs deviating from the tender procedure, for the importing of drugs at exorbitant prices, for the scarcity of essential drugs and shortage of laboratory equipment in the hospital system and for the purchasing of unregistered drugs on the pretext of emergency purchases thereby resulting in deaths and impairments due to their use;

And whereas the Minister of Health has neglected to duly regulate the process of importing drugs to this country in a manner not inconsistent with the guiding principles of State Policy stipulated in Article 27 of the Constitution regardless of the fact that the government is bound to uphold the Principles therein;
And whereas the Minister has acted ruining the safe health service available for people, thereby breaching the pledge he has given in terms of Article 53 of the Constitution;
And whereas the Minister has neglected his fundamental duties required by Article 28 of the Constitution and people have to pay the price of his irresponsible conduct with their lives;
That this Parliament resolves that it has no confidence in the competence of Hon. Keheliya Rambukwella, Minister of Health to function as a Minister of the Cabinet of Ministers any longer."

,. , Waiver of Registration . 360 . , . . . . . Sir, we must be very grateful to the Indian Government and the Indian people for extending a helping hand to the Sri Lankan people to purchase drugs and to come out of the economic debacle we encountered at that time. . . , .

Sir, I would like to refer to the "Report and findings of the Royal College of Anaesthetists, 6th National Audit Project" of May, 2018. Those research findings were published in peer-reviewed journals including "The New England Journal of Medicine" and the "British Medical Journal". Those findings very clearly state that antibiotics were the main cause for anaphylaxis in the United Kingdom, that they had been identified as the culprit agents for 46 per cent of the cases. In conclusion, they have clearly stated that the mortality rate amongst the UK population is approximately 20 to 30 deaths per annum, which is probably an underestimate.

. This is what Dr. Rajan Hoole says. Just six months after the Easter Sunday attacks, he publishes a book titled "Sri Lanka's Easter Tragedy: When the Deep State Gets Out Of Its Depth". , Deep State , . ? His book states this, I quote:
"The book's main argument is that the March 2018 anti-Muslim violence, the failed constitutional coup of October 2018,....."
That is, the coup which sought to remove Hon. Ranil Wickremesinghe from prime ministership.

"...... the following year's devastating Easter attack, the renewed violence against Muslims in May and the Dr. Shafi saga together form part of a single narrative. It deals with attempts to control or minimise the effect of the Muslim vote.

The book brings into focus the Deep State as a body of organised interests comprising dominant sections of the political establishment and the security apparatus, ready and willing to pursue partisan goals in contempt of the law." . . Prof. A. Pathmeswaran 2023 3 " " "The way to achieve health for all" :
"All the people having access to the full range of quality health services they need, when and where they need them, without financial hardship, is what Universal Health Coverage (UHC) is all about."

"This wide issue was what Prof. A. Pathmeswaran tackled under the theme - UHC: From Rhetoric to Reality. He was the Orator at the inauguration of the 28th Annual Academic Sessions 2023 of the College of Community Physicians of Sri Lanka..."
It goes on to state, I quote:
"...essential health services, from health promotion to prevention, treatment, rehabilitation, and palliative care across the life course, he said that we obviously have some way to go to reach UHC.
. The newspaper reports further, I quote:
"Prof. Pathmeswaran suggested the spending of the health budget more efficiently; the collection of appropriate and quality data and also their use to the maximum; and the right distribution of

facilities - beds and manpower such as doctors, nurses etc., along with the right skill mix. It is possible to build and equip hospitals almost anywhere, but sending trained staff to difficult areas is not easy."
"A public health expert says SL must agree on essential services for all without financial hardship, with experts seeking participation of a well-informed public"

" 'To move forward, we must agree on the range of services or essential services that will be available to all without financial hardship,' said Prof. Pathmeswaran, adding that it is not something for experts to decide behind closed doors. "
That means, information with regard to some of these areas should be available.

, ,Substandard medicines are a significant problem in the UK, with a 10-fold increase in the incidents reported over the last 10 years .

, The World Health Organization (WHO) defines substandard medical products as those which are authorized but fail to meet their quality standards....." - I repeat, "which are authorized but fail to meet their quality standards " - "....or specifications and defines falsified medical products as those that deliberately/fraudulently misrepresent their identity, composition or source. Data from the UK and Canada, alongside recent events in both Pakistan and the USA, (and even in one or two instances in Sri Lanka) suggest that substandard medicines are a significant problem and are not restricted to pharmaceutical products from middle-income countries or companies specialising in the manufacture of generic medicines. The data from Canada and the UK show that all companies are associated with substandard medicines. So no medicine can be 100% safe, even Paracetamol (Panadol). That is what the WHO says. And, the document I have here with me states, No NMRA in the world can prevent substandard drugs getting in 100%.

, healthcare worker shortage , According to WHO, the number of healthcare workers worldwide will fall short by 12.9 million in 2035. An ageing workforce, falling numbers in people entering the profession, early retirement, inadequate training and increasing demands from a growing and ageing population are some of the reasons attributed to the global shortage of healthcare

For example, if we take the United Kingdom, this document states, The UK is facing one of the most severe healthcare worker shortage in the world. The NHS (National Health Service), the statutory body responsible for public health service in the country, revealed that in the first half of 2019-20, more than 43,000 nursing posts were unfilled. nursing posts 43,000 fill . , , . ? This is a world scenario; . . , Not just nurses, the Kings Fund reveals that NHS faces an overall shortage of healthcare workers across streams by a massive 100,000 . United Kingdom .

New Zealand . , The land down under, New Zealand, is known for providing some of the best working conditions in the world. With a small population, New Zealand is always on the lookout for highly skilled healthcare workers from overseas and the country needs 25,000 more nurses at the moment.

( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) Next, the Hon. G.G. Ponnambalam. You have fourteen minutes.

.. ( .. ) (The Hon. G.G. Ponnambalam) Hon. Presiding Member, in fact, when, at the very outset, our party signed this No-Confidence Motion against the Hon. Minister of Health, our position was that it is not against him personally, but because there is certainly a situation, as far as we, in the North East, are concerned, where the health sector is seriously wanting.

We have been, for the last two-and-a-half years since we got elected, repeatedly bringing up numerous issues at various times. Unfortunately, none have been attended to, except for just one matter relating to CT scanners not being serviced because there were some disagreements with regard to the amount of money that was being charged by the servicing company. So, except for that matter, everything else has still not been addressed.

Then, a letter had been written in August this year by Dr. T. Sathiyamoorthy, who is the Provincial Director of Health Services of the Northern Province, to the Hon. Minister of Health, copied to the Chief Secretary, Northern Province, Secretary, Ministry of Health and Additional Secretary (Development), Ministry of Health. That letter, Hon. Presiding Member, gives a list of immediate things that need to be attended to. The Primary Healthcare System Strengthening Project has been implemented from 2019 onwards. However, 30 hospitals are without approved cadres for nursing officers. So, Madam, there is an urgent need for approval of cadres for the hospitals under the "DRIVE" project funded by the Netherlands. The Provincial Director of Health Services of the Northern Province has made it very clear that, with the current staff members, it is very difficult to make those units functional. In the Northern Province, there has been 1,906 vacancies existing from 30th April, 2023 and that situation has not improved. If we take human resource development, there are 89 vacancies out of a cadre of 161 for consultants. Like that, Madam, the appointment of intern medical officers, appointment of nursing officers, appointment of PSM category staff, dispensers' issues, appointment of public health staff like PHIs and PHMs, transfer of Tamil-speaking midwives from the Central Province to the Northern Province - it has been five years since they had been appointed to the Central Province and they have been asking for transfers back to the Northern Province, but yet, those have not been implemented - appointment of minor staff and other shortcomings have been listed and written about in detail to the Hon. Minister.

But, so far - I checked even today - there has been absolutely no progress in this regard. Those are not new issues; those are matters that have been raised constantly for the past several months, if not years, but they still remain unanswered.

It is for those reasons, Hon. Presiding Member, that our party has decided that we will vote in favour of the No-confidence Motion. Our view is, as far as the North and the East are concerned, areas that were affected by war, where already the health sector is lagging and the needs of which the Hon. Minister knows especially because of war victims, the situation is quite grave. Not only patients in the Northern Province, but even those from adjoining provinces outside the North-East also come to the North for treatments.

( ) (The Hon. Keheliya Rambukwella) Hon. Member, I appreciate your concern. As of now, we take into consideration the 2017 cadre provisions. Every three years, we are supposed to do a review, but we had done the last review in 2017. We are short of a human resource of almost 14,000. So, what we have done is, we have made a request to the Department of Management Services and to the President and he said that soon after the Budget, he will at least approve 50 per cent of it, which will make the system manageable. As of now, I will not be able to given you any assurances. So, I have been trying, but we have been unable to do recruitments because there is a blanket cover prohibiting that.
( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) Thank you, Hon. Minister.

.. ( .. ) (The Hon. G.G. Ponnambalam) I hope you do that, Hon. Minister, because I can remember that I gave you a written document about those matters as soon as you were appointed Minister of Health and you gave me the same assurance, but it has not been done. So, please, look into it because already the health sector has been very badly affected.

Hon. Presiding Member, during the next Sitting week, there will be an Adjournment Debate on the Easter Sunday Bombings. Unfortunately, my Colleague, the Hon. Selvarajah Kajendren, and I will not be able to take part in it. So, I wish to raise a few matters, particularly the exposures that came out of the Channel 4 documentary. Madam, the matters raised in that documentary are things that the people of the North and the East, particularly the Tamil people, are quite familiar with. We have been raising issues with regard to how counterinsurgency measures had been put into operation by the then Government right through the war. I remember, when I was a Member of Parliament from 2001 to 2010, that we constantly raised issues at that time when the war was taking place about the way in which the military establishment of the State was acting in the North and the East. However, the polarized situation was such that nobody was willing to listen to what we were saying. And you, Hon. Presiding Member, as an academic who can take a rather dispassionate consideration of these matters, would know that when it

comes to counterinsurgency and particularly when it comes to war, the truth is the first casualty and hardly anything that is told in public is, in fact, true. So, it is under those circumstances this Channel 4 exposure with regard to the Easter Sunday Bombings actually has to be seen in context. Out of that exposure, one of two things can be concluded. The worst case scenario is that the Government itself was directly involved in the planning of those bombings in order for whatever beneficial consequences those could arise, electorally or otherwise. The best case scenario for the then Government is that they knew that those bombings were going to take place; they knew full well that there was already a process on by certain extremist elements to carry out certain things and what they did was that, through their contacts within the military intelligence apparatus, in some way, they managed to influence them at best with regard to how they should act and when they could have taken steps to prevent it, they chose not to.

They, knowing fully well that there will be severe casualties, decided not to prevent it and also going further, actually manipulated the situation so that it happens in a particular way. That is the best possible explanation that could be given, and the worst is that they themselves were directly behind the bombings. Madam Presiding Member, this is not the first time that evidence of this sort of behaviour by the defence establishment had been exposed. There is a WikiLeaks dispatch by the Charge dAffaires of the US Embassy, Mr. James R. Moore, to the Secretary of State of the United States dated 05th of May, 2009, where he says - at that time the President was the Hon. Mahinda Rajapaksa - I quote:

The President then claimed that the Government forces would not shell civilian areas, confiding that the Army has Deep Penetration Units (Tamil-speaking agents operating in LTTE-controlled areas) within the safe zone who are attempting to organize people to breach the LTTE earth berms and allow civilians to escape.

What I am saying here, Hon. Presiding Member, is that such was the way in which the military was able to infiltrate, such was the way in which they operated at that time that they were part and parcel of identifying themselves and mingling with the LTTE. That is what they had admitted doing to the United States Embassy.

Then, President Ranil Wickremesinghe, on the 06th of October, 2020 when he gave evidence before the Presidential Commission of Inquiry on the Easter bombings - it was reported in the newspapers on 07th of October, 2020 - had admitted that the military intelligence wing has always wanted to divide the Tamil-speaking people into Tamils and Muslims and for the Muslims to claim a separate identity, for that purpose, they worked extremely hard to create rifts between the Tamils and the Muslims by doing various activities, which ultimately led people like former Hon. Minister M. H. M. Ashraff, who was a strong advocate of the Tamil-speaking peoples identity and was a member of the ITAK, the Federal Party, to eventually choose to espouse a separate identity completely. So, what this shows, Madam Presiding Member, is that the nature in which the military operates is so secretive and very subversive that the truth is almost

impossible to obtain from within. In the case of the Easter Sunday bombings, Madam, it is a particular party that is being accused of. But when it is an ethnic conflict that polarizes and when the ethnic dimensions of this country are such that it will always be the Sinhalese majority that governs, then the whole State apparatus will be ethnically biased and for the truth to come out, you need an international investigation. I am telling the Hon. Members, if you have a conscience, if you want to know the truth and if you want to know why the Tamils feel so victimized and so polarized, then ask yourselves, if you do not arrive at the truth, can you convince the Tamils that there is a future for them as well? The only way you can do that is through an international investigation. I cannot understand why you all should run away from it. The Hon. Field Marshal Sarath Fonseka, yesterday - I got to know through the newspapers - had, in fact, said that he wants an international investigation for the Easter Sunday bombings. That, I welcome. But, that same international investigation must happen with regard to the war.

The Hon. Members opposite and those on this side, accuse our party of being pro-LTTE. The LTTE is accused of crimes. If we are pro-LTTE and if we are requesting to have an international investigation, we are not running away from the LTTE being investigated. If we are not frightened, why are you? Why are you frightened unless you have all of this to hide?

I appeal to you all - this country has hit rock bottom - to, at least, start afresh so that the truth comes out, everybody comes to know what happened and we can make sure that we do not repeat that in the future. That is the only way, Hon. Madam Presiding Member, that we can find genuine, lasting solutions for the problems this country faces.

It being past 5.30 p.m., THE HON. SPEAKER adjourned Parliament without Question put.
Parliament adjourned accordingly at 5.45 p.m until 9.30 a.m. on Tuesday, 19th September, 2023.
